Description: Terracotta portable cooking stove fragment. Mould-made front is a pot-support with a theatre mask of Papposilenos or satyr within a rectangular panel. The back is plain; part of the fire-bowl and its wide everted rim survive. Red slip, eyes painted black (?). The support and panel were made in a one-piece mould. Micaceous orange- brown clay, mica and white inclusions. Bottom cut away neatly, possibly pre firing. Possibly used as tile rather than stove.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Appears to have been joined at back, bottom cut away pre-firing. Ptolemaic parallel (Dunand 1990, no. 1006) and close parallel in Alexandria Museum (Didelot 1998, 286-7, fig. 16). Dunand, F. 1990. Catalogue des Terres cuites gréco-romaines d’Egypte. Musée du louvre. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (LA.03) (Phase 3)
